Topic: Draw two habitats and the different living things in each
CAN: The student can draw and label two different types of habitats, such as a simple forest scene and a pond scene, although details may be minimal.
The student can draw and label a few plants for each habitat, such as trees or bushes in the forest and some simple aquatic plants in the pond.
CANNOT: The student is likely unable to accurately draw or label several types of animals unique to each habitat, as they might include animals that don't belong (e.g., drawing a bear in the pond) or not label them (student doesnâ€™t know or is unsure).
The student may struggle to draw clear comparisons between the habitats, providing limited visual evidence of how the living things differ (student does not see or understand the differences).
The student may not effectively group similar plants and animals within each habitat, placing unrelated organisms together (e.g., grouping a fish with a squirrel in the forest habitat).
